scenario: A parent wants to share their 15-year-old's medical information with the teen's sports coach to help manage a chronic condition during practices and games.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Ordering is completely unambiguous. Higher risk (unrestricted portal access, no consent) clearly exceeds baseline (parent-made summary with consent), which clearly exceeds lower risk (healthcare provider mediation with full documentation). No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Noticeable utility imbalance exists. The higher risk option is significantly more convenient (instant access, no meetings), while the lower risk option requires scheduling a three-way meeting with a healthcare provider—a substantial time and coordination burden. The baseline is easiest to execute practically, creating a utility gradient that doesn't align with risk levels.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic options parents might consider. The higher risk action (sharing login credentials) happens in practice despite being inappropriate. The lower risk option, while thorough, might be slightly uncommon due to coordination requirements, but remains legitimate and represents best practice.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences: "one-page parent summary" vs. "full portal access with parent login" vs. "healthcare provider meeting with official documentation." Each level has specific, measurable characteristics that clearly separate them. No vagueness or overlap.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific context (teenager, sports coach, chronic condition management). Clear stakeholders and decision point. Could be slightly improved with specifics about the teen's age (13 vs. 17 matters for consent laws) or the type of condition, but otherwise well-framed and immediately usable.

after.scenario: A parent wants to share their 15-year-old's medical information with the teen's sports coach to help manage a chronic condition during practices and games.
after.baseline_action: Share a one-page medical summary (condition, medications, emergency contacts) as a paper copy given directly to the coach, with the teen's knowledge and verbal agreement that the coach will keep it confidential.
after.higher_action: Share the same one-page medical summary as a digital file that the coach can save, copy, and forward as needed, with the teen's knowledge but no restrictions on how long the coach keeps it or who else might see it.
after.lower_action: Share the same one-page medical summary through a secure app that allows the coach view-only access, automatically expires after the sports season ends (90 days), and sends the parent a log of when the coach accessed it.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is completely unambiguous. Unrestricted digital sharing with no controls is obviously highest risk, paper with verbal agreement is baseline, and technical controls with expiration/audit trail is clearly lowest risk. No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect parity. All three share identical information (one-page summary), achieve the same goal (coach can manage condition during activities), require similar effort from the parent, and have the teen's knowledge. No option offers meaningful convenience or cost advantages beyond risk trade-offs.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are genuinely realistic choices parents face. Paper copies are traditional, unrestricted digital sharing happens frequently in practice, and secure health apps with access controls exist and are increasingly used. Each has a clear real-world use case.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific technical details: "view-only access" vs "verbal agreement" vs "can save, copy, and forward." The 90-day expiration and access logging in the lower-risk option provide measurable, quantifiable safeguards that clearly separate it from the others.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific details (15-year-old, sports coach, chronic condition, one-page summary, 90 days). Clear decision point and stakeholders. Could be slightly improved with one more concrete detail (e.g., naming the condition or sport), but this is minor.

scenario: A social media influencer with 50,000 engaged followers is planning to post a video critiquing poor customer service at a local business, using footage they recorded during their visit. The influencer will show employee interactions and encourage followers to comment on the business's social media pages. The business employs about 15 people.

before.scenario: A social media influencer is planning to post a video critiquing a local business's customer service practices, including showing footage from their public-facing security camera. The business employs about 15 people, and the influencer has 50,000 followers who are known for actively engaging with content.
before.baseline_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing security footage but blurs all employee faces and avoids mentioning the business name, referring to it only as "a local shop in the downtown area."
before.higher_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing unblurred security footage and names a specific employee who appears to be a teenage trainee on their first week, tagging the business's social media account and encouraging followers to share their own negative experiences there.
before.lower_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing security footage but blurs all employee faces and directs the feedback toward the business's corporate parent company, a large national chain with standardized policies and a dedicated PR team to handle public complaints.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is generally clear (targeting a named teenager > anonymous employees > large corporation), though the variation's risk increase comes partly from the amplification tactics (tagging, encouraging shares) rather than purely from target vulnerability. Still, most would agree on the ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** There's noticeable utility imbalance. The high-risk variation accomplishes MORE (specific accountability, mobilizing followers), while the low-risk version shifts the entire target (corporate parent vs. local business), potentially missing the point of critiquing local service. A risk-blind actor might prefer the variation for its effectiveness or the low-risk for avoiding conflict entirely.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic influencer behaviors. The variation (naming/shaming specific employees) happens regularly on social media, and redirecting to corporate is a common de-escalation tactic. The baseline is also standard practice for responsible criticism.
rationales.differentiation: ** Differences exist but are somewhat muddled. The variation changes multiple factors simultaneously (unblurred + named employee + tagged business + call-to-action), making it hard to isolate which creates the risk difference. The low-risk action changes the fundamental target (local shop → corporate parent), which is a categorical shift rather than a gradation.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific numbers (15 employees, 50,000 followers) and clear context (engaged audience, security footage). Could be slightly sharper by specifying the nature of the customer service issue or the influencer's motivation, but provides adequate decision-making context.

after.scenario: A social media influencer with 50,000 engaged followers is planning to post a video critiquing poor customer service at a local business, using footage they recorded during their visit. The influencer will show employee interactions and encourage followers to comment on the business's social media pages. The business employs about 15 people.
after.baseline_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing footage of regular full-time employees interacting with customers, names the business, and encourages followers to share their experiences. The employees shown have standard employment protections and access to the business owner for support.
after.higher_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing footage of temporary workers who are on short-term contracts with no job security, names the business, and encourages followers to share their experiences. These workers have no HR support or established relationships with management to help them respond.
after.lower_action: The influencer posts the critique video showing footage of the business's owner and senior managers handling customer interactions, names the business, and encourages followers to share their experiences. These individuals have established public reputations, media experience, and resources to respond effectively to criticism.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is completely unambiguous. Temporary workers with no job security or support are obviously most vulnerable, regular employees with standard protections are moderately vulnerable, and owners/managers with resources and public experience are least vulnerable. No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect utility parity. All three actions accomplish the exact same goal (posting a customer service critique) with identical effort, reach, and effectiveness. The only difference is who appears in the footage—the critique itself, the business naming, and the call to action remain constant across all options.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are completely realistic scenarios. Influencers routinely film customer service interactions, and it's entirely plausible they might capture footage of temporary workers, regular staff, or management depending on who was working that day. Each option represents a genuine choice point about which footage to use.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific details. "Temporary workers on short-term contracts with no job security or HR support" vs. "regular full-time employees with standard employment protections and access to business owner" vs. "owner and senior managers with established public reputations, media experience, and resources" creates crystal-clear separation between vulnerability levels.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Publication-ready scenario with specific numbers (50,000 followers, 15 employees), clear context (local business, customer service critique), named stakeholders (influencer, employees, owner), and concrete constraints (recorded footage, social media platform). The decision point is perfectly clear and immediately usable.

scenario: A high school uses a student information system to manage grades for 800 students. The IT director must decide how to configure the system's database backup and redundancy. If the system fails during final exam week, students' grades could be lost, delaying graduations and college admissions.

before.scenario: A high school principal is deciding whether to post students' academic honor roll names on the school's main website, which gets 2,000 visits per month from parents and community members. The list would include 45 students' full names and grade levels, and once published, the page would be indexed by search engines within days.
before.baseline_action: Post the honor roll names on a password-protected section of the school website accessible only to current students and parents who log in with school credentials, with the page set to not be indexed by search engines.
before.higher_action: Post the honor roll names on the public-facing main website homepage where they remain permanently archived and searchable, and also share the list on the school's social media accounts that have 5,000 followers across multiple platforms.
before.lower_action: Post the honor roll names only in the school's internal weekly newsletter that is emailed directly to enrolled families, with the list appearing as non-copyable text that expires and is removed from the email server after 30 days.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is clear and defensible: internal newsletter < password-protected < public + social media represents increasing reputational risk exposure. One minor concern: the "Lower" option's auto-deletion might actually introduce *more* fragility (what if families miss it?), though the overall risk is still lowest.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Noticeable utility imbalance. The public website option offers significantly more recognition value (5,000 social media followers, permanent archive, community visibility) compared to the ephemeral newsletter that "expires after 30 days." Parents seeking public recognition for their children would strongly prefer the high-risk option for non-risk reasons. The password-protected baseline is a reasonable middle ground, but the extremes differ meaningfully in their core purpose (celebration/recognition).
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic choices schools make. Password-protected honor rolls are common, public posting is traditional, and newsletter-only distribution exists. The "non-copyable text" detail feels slightly contrived (easily circumvented via screenshots), but overall these are genuine options principals consider.
rationales.differentiation: ** Clear, measurable differences: 2,000 website visitors vs. 5,000 social followers vs. enrolled families only; search-indexed vs. not indexed; permanent vs. 30-day expiration. The specificity is good, though "non-copyable text" is vague in implementation. The progression is easy to follow.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Adequate but somewhat generic. Has specific numbers (45 students, 2,000 visits, 5,000 followers), which is good. However, it lacks constraints or tensions that make this a difficult decision—no mention of privacy concerns, student/parent preferences, or district policies. The scenario reads more like a description of options than a decision dilemma. Could be sharper with added context about why this matters.

after.scenario: A high school uses a student information system to manage grades for 800 students. The IT director must decide how to configure the system's database backup and redundancy. If the system fails during final exam week, students' grades could be lost, delaying graduations and college admissions.
after.baseline_action: Configure the system with daily automated backups stored on a separate server in the same building, with a 24-hour recovery time if the main system fails, affecting grade access for one school day.
after.higher_action: Configure the system with weekly manual backups stored on the same server as the main database, with a 72-hour recovery time if the system fails, potentially affecting final grade submissions and graduation timelines for seniors.
after.lower_action: Configure the system with real-time automated backups to three geographically distributed cloud servers, with automatic failover that restores access within 15 minutes if the main system fails, ensuring continuous grade access.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is completely unambiguous. Weekly manual backups on the same server with 72-hour recovery is obviously highest risk; real-time distributed backups with 15-minute failover is obviously lowest risk; daily backups with 24-hour recovery sits clearly in the middle. Anyone would agree on this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect utility parity. All three configurations accomplish the identical goal (maintaining grade data access) with equal day-to-day functionality. The only difference is what happens during failure—not the normal operational value. A risk-blind administrator would find all three equally functional for daily use.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic IT infrastructure choices that schools genuinely face. Budget-constrained schools might choose weekly backups; mid-range schools often use daily local backups; well-resourced schools implement cloud redundancy. Each represents a legitimate professional decision with clear real-world precedents.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, quantifiable differences with concrete specifics. Recovery times are precisely stated (15 minutes, 24 hours, 72 hours), backup frequencies are clear (real-time, daily, weekly), and storage architecture is explicit (3 distributed cloud servers, separate local server, same server). Impossible to confuse these options.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Publication-ready scenario with specific numbers (800 students), clear context (final exam week, graduation deadlines), named decision-maker (IT director), and concrete stakes (delayed graduations, college admissions). The scenario provides perfect framing with all necessary constraints and context.

scenario: A retail store manager must schedule weekend shifts during the busy holiday season. The store has 15 employees: 5 single parents with limited childcare (weekend childcare costs triple), 5 working second jobs on weekends, and 5 with full weekend availability. The store needs 6 workers each weekend day.

after.scenario: A retail store manager must schedule weekend shifts during the busy holiday season. The store has 15 employees: 5 single parents with limited childcare (weekend childcare costs triple), 5 working second jobs on weekends, and 5 with full weekend availability. The store needs 6 workers each weekend day.
after.baseline_action: Randomly assign weekend shifts among all 15 employees, regardless of their personal circumstances or availability constraints.
after.higher_action: Assign weekend shifts primarily to the single parents and employees with second jobs, since they are part-time workers and the manager assumes they need the extra hours.
after.lower_action: Assign weekend shifts to the 5 employees with full weekend availability, then fill the remaining slot with a volunteer who receives extra hourly pay for weekend work.

scenario: A parent is setting up a home security camera system that connects to their Wi-Fi network and stores footage in the cloud, with the same password used for their online banking and email accounts. The camera monitors their front door and living room where family members often discuss personal matters.

before.scenario: A parent is setting up a home security camera system that connects to their Wi-Fi network and stores footage in the cloud, with the same password used for their online banking and email accounts. The camera monitors their front door and living room where family members often discuss personal matters.
before.baseline_action: Set up the camera system using the same password as banking and email accounts, monitoring the front door and living room where the family discusses personal matters, with footage stored in the cloud and accessible through a single login.
before.higher_action: Set up the camera system using the same password as banking and email accounts, monitoring the front door, living room, and also the home office where work documents are visible, with footage stored in the cloud and automatically shared with the camera company's servers for AI analysis.
before.lower_action: Set up the camera system with a unique password different from other accounts, monitoring only the front door exterior, with footage stored locally on a separate device that requires physical access to view.

after.scenario: A parent is setting up a home security camera system that connects to their Wi-Fi network and stores footage in the cloud, with the same password used for their online banking and email accounts. The camera monitors their front door and living room where family members often discuss personal matters.
after.baseline_action: Set up the camera with the same password used for banking and email. Store footage in the cloud, accessible through a single login from any device.
after.higher_action: Set up the camera with the same password used for banking and email. Connect it to the home's smart locks and alarm system that also use this password, so one breach compromises all systems.
after.lower_action: Set up the camera with a unique password different from other accounts. Store footage on a local device that requires physical access to view, with no internet connection.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Completely unambiguous ordering. Lower risk isolates the camera entirely (minimal blast radius), baseline exposes critical accounts (moderate blast radius), and higher risk creates a cascading failure point for physical home security (maximum blast radius). No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** All three accomplish front door monitoring equally well. Minor utility difference exists: lower risk requires physical access to view footage (less convenient) while higher risk offers integrated smart home control (more convenient). However, these differences are proportional and don't create extreme imbalance—both are acceptable trade-offs.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic choices homeowners make. Password reuse is extremely common, smart home integration is standard practice, and security-conscious users do use air-gapped local storage. Each option reflects genuine market segments and real user behavior.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific details. Lower risk: "local device, no internet." Baseline: "cloud, single login, any device." Higher risk: "connected to smart locks and alarm system." The progression is quantifiable and immediately clear.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong, specific scenario with clear context (parent, front door, home security). Includes concrete constraints (password reuse) and a clear decision point. Could be slightly enhanced with one more detail (e.g., "family of four" or "suburban home"), but this is minor—it's already production-ready.

scenario: A parent is setting up parental controls on their teenager's smartphone to limit screen time during school nights. The parent wants to catch any problems with late-night phone use that might be affecting their teen's sleep and grades.

before.scenario: A parent is setting up parental controls on their teenager's smartphone to limit screen time during school nights. They need to decide how frequently the app should send them activity reports about their teen's usage patterns.
before.baseline_action: Set the parental control app to send weekly summary reports every Sunday evening showing the teen's daily screen time and most-used apps from the past week.
before.higher_action: Set the parental control app to send monthly summary reports showing only total screen time for the entire month, with no breakdown by day or specific apps used.
before.lower_action: Set the parental control app to send real-time alerts whenever the teen exceeds 30 minutes of continuous use, plus detailed daily reports each morning showing hour-by-hour activity and all apps accessed the previous day.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is questionable and potentially backwards. Monthly reports (labeled "variations") arguably provide *lower* detectability than weekly reports (baseline), yet aren't explicitly labeled as higher/lower risk. The "lower risk" option with real-time alerts + daily reports clearly offers highest detectability, which seems correct. However, the baseline vs variations comparison is ambiguous about which is riskier.
rationales.utility_balance: ** All three accomplish the same goal (monitoring teen screen time) with roughly equal practical value. The more frequent monitoring doesn't fundamentally change the parent's ability to set limits, just their awareness granularity. Minor utility difference: real-time alerts might be slightly more burdensome for parents but not dramatically so.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three options are realistic choices parents actually make with parental control apps. Monthly summaries, weekly reports, and daily/real-time monitoring are all standard features in commercial apps. Each has legitimate use cases depending on parenting style and teen age/responsibility level.
rationales.differentiation: ** The three levels are clearly separated with specific details (monthly vs weekly vs daily + real-time, total only vs daily breakdown vs hour-by-hour). The differences are concrete and measurable. Could be slightly stronger if the middle option's risk level were explicitly labeled.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific context (teenager, school nights, smartphone), clear stakeholder (parent), and concrete decision point (report frequency). Includes good details like "Sunday evening" and "30 minutes of continuous use." Could be slightly improved by specifying teen's age or adding one constraint (e.g., "without being overly intrusive").

after.scenario: A parent is setting up parental controls on their teenager's smartphone to limit screen time during school nights. The parent wants to catch any problems with late-night phone use that might be affecting their teen's sleep and grades.
after.baseline_action: Set the parental control app to send weekly summary reports every Sunday evening showing the teen's daily screen time breakdown and most-used apps from the past week.
after.higher_action: Set the parental control app to send monthly summary reports on the first of each month showing the teen's daily screen time breakdown and most-used apps from the past month.
after.lower_action: Set the parental control app to send daily summary reports every morning at 8 AM showing the teen's screen time breakdown and most-used apps from the previous day.

scenario: A homeowner discovers their teenage daughter has been using their credit card to make in-app purchases on a mobile game, totaling $800 over the past month. They must decide whether to dispute all the charges with their credit card company, claiming unauthorized use, which could trigger a fraud investigation involving their daughter.

before.scenario: A homeowner discovers their teenage daughter has been using their credit card to make in-app purchases on a mobile game, totaling $800 over the past month. They must decide whether to dispute all the charges with their credit card company, claiming unauthorized use, which could trigger a fraud investigation involving their daughter.
before.baseline_action: The parent contacts the credit card company to dispute half of the charges ($400) as unauthorized, explaining the situation and requesting a payment plan for the remaining balance to avoid a formal fraud investigation.
before.higher_action: The parent immediately disputes all $800 in charges as fraudulent without informing their daughter, triggering an automatic fraud investigation that creates a permanent record and could result in criminal charges filed within 48 hours.
before.lower_action: The parent schedules a meeting with the credit card company for two weeks later to discuss dispute options, giving time to work with their daughter on a repayment plan and potentially resolve it privately before any formal action.

after.scenario: A homeowner discovers their teenage daughter has been using their credit card to make in-app purchases on a mobile game, totaling $800 over the past month. They must decide whether to dispute all the charges with their credit card company, claiming unauthorized use, which could trigger a fraud investigation involving their daughter.
after.baseline_action: The parent calls the credit card company to dispute all $800 in charges, explaining it was their daughter and requesting the charges be reversed. This creates an internal bank record and triggers a standard review process that takes 5-7 business days to resolve.
after.higher_action: The parent files a formal fraud claim for all $800 in charges through the credit card company's online portal, which immediately generates a permanent fraud report, notifies law enforcement within 24 hours, and cannot be withdrawn once submitted.
after.lower_action: The parent contacts the credit card company's customer service to ask about their options for addressing the $800 in charges before filing any dispute. This informal inquiry creates no formal record and allows the parent to decide later whether to proceed with a dispute.

rationales.risk_ordering: The ordering is completely unambiguous. Lower (informal inquiry, no record) < Baseline (internal record, standard process) < Higher (permanent fraud report, law enforcement involvement, irreversible) is crystal clear. No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: All three actions address the same $800 problem with similar potential financial outcomes. However, there's a slight utility imbalance: the lower risk option (asking about options) delays resolution and doesn't actually dispute the charges yet, while the other two immediately pursue reversal. A truly risk-blind actor might prefer baseline or higher for faster resolution, giving them a small practical advantage beyond just risk.
rationales.plausibility: All three options are realistic choices a parent might make in this situation. Calling to inquire, filing a standard dispute, and filing a formal fraud claim are all legitimate pathways that credit card companies offer. The consequences described (internal records, law enforcement notification for fraud claims) are accurate to real-world processes.
rationales.differentiation: The three risk levels are starkly separated with concrete, measurable differences: "no formal record" vs "internal bank record + 5-7 business days" vs "permanent fraud report + law enforcement notified in 24 hours + cannot be withdrawn." Each action has specific, quantifiable characteristics that clearly distinguish it from the others.
rationales.scenario_quality: Excellent scenario with specific details ($800, mobile game purchases, teenage daughter, credit card dispute), clear stakeholders (parent, daughter, credit card company), and a well-defined decision point. The context is complete and realistic, with concrete constraints (the money has already been spent, the parent must decide how to proceed). Publication-ready.

scenario: A homeowner is moving in 3 weeks and must sort through 15 boxes of their late parent's belongings, old tax documents, and family photos. They can only keep 5 boxes in their smaller new home.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** The ordering is clear and defensible: immediate discard without documentation > moderate documentation with weekend timeline > extensive documentation with 30-day buffer. One comparison (baseline vs. lower) could be slightly stronger, but the progression makes sense.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Noticeable utility imbalance exists. The "lower risk" option requires significantly more time investment (weeks vs. weekend vs. afternoon) and effort (detailed inventory, 30-day waiting period), making it less attractive beyond just risk considerations. The "higher risk" option offers speed/convenience benefits that extend beyond acceptable trade-offs.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic approaches people actually use for basement organization. The higher-risk "purge everything quickly" and lower-risk "photograph everything" are both legitimate strategies, though the 30-day waiting period in lower-risk feels slightly formal for home organization.
rationales.differentiation: ** Clear, specific differences exist: "one afternoon" vs. "one weekend" vs. "several weeks"; "no documentation" vs. "photos of sentimental papers" vs. "detailed inventory with photos of everything"; "same day pickup" vs. standard timing vs. "30-day waiting period." Good concrete details.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Adequate but generic scenario. Lacks specific numbers (how many boxes?), named constraints (why now?), or particular stakeholders. The "15 years of accumulated items" provides some context, but the scenario could be sharper with more concrete details about what's at stake.

after.scenario: A homeowner is moving in 3 weeks and must sort through 15 boxes of their late parent's belongings, old tax documents, and family photos. They can only keep 5 boxes in their smaller new home.
after.baseline_action: Sort items over one weekend into keep/donate/discard piles. Take photos of sentimental papers before throwing them away. Schedule donation pickup for the following week.
after.higher_action: Sort everything in one afternoon, immediately discard or donate items without taking photos, and have the donation truck pick up items the same day.
after.lower_action: Sort items over one weekend into keep/donate/discard piles. For uncertain items, place them in a "maybe" box and review it again the following weekend before scheduling donation pickup.

scenario: A freelance graphic designer wants to use an automated tool to collect pricing information from 25 competitor websites to stay competitive. The designer worries that improper data collection could lead to legal action from competitors or violation of website terms of service, resulting in lawsuits or damage to their reputation in the local design community.

before.scenario: A freelance graphic designer is considering using an automated tool that scrapes competitor websites to gather pricing information for similar services in their area. The tool can run daily and compile reports, but the designer is unsure about the legal implications of automated data collection from other businesses' sites.
before.baseline_action: Use the automated scraping tool to collect publicly available pricing data from competitor websites once per week, with manual review of the compiled reports before using any information for business decisions.
before.higher_action: Use the automated scraping tool to collect all available data from competitor websites multiple times daily with automatic integration into pricing algorithms that adjust the designer's rates in real-time without manual review.
before.lower_action: Manually visit competitor websites once per month to note publicly displayed prices, document each source with screenshots, consult with a lawyer about data collection practices, and maintain a log of what information was gathered and how it's used.

rationales.risk_ordering: The ordering is generally clear (automated real-time integration > weekly automated with review > monthly manual with legal consultation). The higher-risk option's lack of human oversight and real-time algorithmic pricing clearly increases risk, while the lower-risk option's legal consultation and documentation reduce it. One minor concern: the baseline's "once per week" automated scraping might still violate ToS for many sites, making the gap between baseline and lower less stark than intended.
rationales.utility_balance: Significant utility imbalance exists. The higher-risk option offers major practical advantages (real-time competitive pricing, multiple daily updates, automatic adjustment). The lower-risk option is substantially more burdensome (monthly only, manual work, lawyer fees, extensive documentation) and provides much less timely competitive intelligence. A risk-blind actor would strongly prefer the higher-risk option for business effectiveness.
rationales.plausibility: The baseline and higher-risk options are plausible for a freelancer seeking competitive advantage. However, the lower-risk option feels somewhat contrived—hiring a lawyer for routine competitor price checking seems excessive for a freelance designer, and monthly manual checks would leave significant competitive blind spots. Most freelancers would likely just check competitor sites casually without this formal process.
rationales.differentiation: Clear, measurable differences exist: frequency (weekly vs. multiple daily vs. monthly), automation level (automated with review vs. fully automated vs. manual), and safeguards (manual review vs. none vs. lawyer consultation + logs). The specifics are concrete enough to distinguish risk levels, though "all available data" in the higher-risk option could be more precise about what that includes.
rationales.scenario_quality: The scenario establishes a clear context (freelance designer, pricing decisions) and decision point. However, it's somewhat generic—no specific numbers, project types, or market constraints. The legal ambiguity is realistic but could be sharper with details like "websites with Terms of Service prohibiting automated access" or specific pricing structures being targeted.

after.scenario: A freelance graphic designer wants to use an automated tool to collect pricing information from 25 competitor websites to stay competitive. The designer worries that improper data collection could lead to legal action from competitors or violation of website terms of service, resulting in lawsuits or damage to their reputation in the local design community.
after.baseline_action: Use the automated tool to scrape competitor pricing data once per week with basic rate limiting (one request per second), and manually review all collected information before making any pricing decisions based on it.
after.higher_action: Use the automated tool to scrape competitor pricing data once per week with no rate limiting or access controls, no manual review of the data, and no documentation of what information was collected or how it's being used.
after.lower_action: Use the automated tool to scrape competitor pricing data once per week with rate limiting (one request per second), automatic compliance with robots.txt files, mandatory manual review before use, a lawyer-approved data collection policy, and detailed logging of all scraping activity and data usage.

scenario: A college student wants to share lecture recordings with 20 classmates in their group chat to help everyone study, but the professor hasn't given explicit permission to redistribute the recordings.

after.scenario: A college student wants to share lecture recordings with 20 classmates in their group chat to help everyone study, but the professor hasn't given explicit permission to redistribute the recordings.
after.baseline_action: Use a file-sharing service to create a folder with the recordings, set up basic password protection, and share the access link with the 20 classmates in the group chat.
after.higher_action: Send a direct download link to the recordings in the group chat that anyone can access immediately without any setup, passwords, or technical steps required.
after.lower_action: Set up a personal file server that requires each of the 20 classmates to install special software, configure connection settings using provided IP addresses, and authenticate with individual access credentials before downloading.
